newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: FORECAST-NZ Telecom's heyday may be over-analysts.
newsitem.headline: FORECAST-NZ Telecom's heyday may be over-analysts.

text.p: Telecom Corp of New Zealand's days of posting ever-burgeoning profits may be over, analysts said on Friday.

"I think the operating environment is certainly very difficult and it is quite possible that we won't see earnings growing at as fast a rate as has traditionally been the case," said Merrill Lynch analyst Michelle Eisig.

The phone utility's bottom line profit for the year to March, due on Wednesday, could come in well below last year's $716.8 million, due mainly to abnormal costs and provisions that are something of an unknown quantity.

Telecom has already indicated that a provision of $35-55 million would be made for loss-making Australian subsidiary Pacific Star, which it is currently in the process of divesting. Whether Pacific Star's fourth quarter operating losses are covered by that provision is uncertain.

The company has also said it is considering inclusion of millennium provisions in its 1997 financial statements that would run to "tens of millions" of dollars. The costs involve adjusting computers to account for the year 2000.
Analysts said the restructure costs for Telecom's Design Build and Maintenance Division were also unclear.
Add to that the start-up costs associated with Telecom's Internet vehicle Xtra and pay-tv operation First Media, and the bottom line profit could easily be in the region of $650-660 million.

Even without the one-offs, analysts expect a flat profit of around NZ$718 million. That forecast includes the losses incurred by Pacific Star in the first three quarters but excludes the possible one-offs alluded to by Telecom.
"But we're not too worried about the bottom line," said Doyle Paterson Brown analyst Kevin Bennett.
"Our focus really is on the operating performance."
Telecom's core earnings growth has slowed in the troughing New Zealand economy.
"We certainly saw in the third quarter of the 1997 financial year that earnings growth in the core businesses was not tracking at as strong a rate as has traditionally been the case," Eisig said.
"I'm sure part of it at least is attributable to very weak economic conditions."
Cellular earnings are expected to be flat as a result of the economic downturn because, as one analyst put it, "in a slowing economy, the first thing I would stop using is my cell phone".
But there are concerns that Telecom's earnings growth has been arrested by more than just the sluggish economy, and that the company's halcyon days are over.
"I personally don't believe it's a short-term aberration. I think Telecom have seen their non-contestable products and services come under attack," said one analyst, who declined to be named.
"Some are still very bullish on the future for Telecom, but at the moment I wouldn't be one of them. Where is the growth going to continue to come from? It's a small market."
It is an opinion investors seem to have shared this year. Telecom shares have fallen from a peak of $7.60 in early January to $6.70 on Friday. They have traded as low as $6.27.

Analysts agreed profit concerns would continue to dog Telecom for some time to come, but Bennett said the fact that core earnings were growing even modestly was a credit to the company in the current economic environment.
"It would have been very difficult for Telecom to continue growing at 15 percent-plus per annum ad infinitum, just because of the size of the company and the economy," he said.
"Now they're moving into a highly competitive environment, and yes, the return will be less. But I still think the stock is well managed and has growth prospects."
Bennett expects Telecom's fourth quarter profit to come in at around $200 million, up from $196.6 million a year ago.
He said Telecom could be expected to achieve operating leverage from a stronger economy in calendar 1998 and would be better focused once rid of its Pacific Star millstone.
